title: 111_hr3923
content: The Act is titled the "Sugar Loaf Fire Protection District Land Exchange Act" and includes definitions for various terms. The Act defines terms such as "District" as the Sugar Loaf Fire Protection District of Boulder, Colorado, "Federal land" as specific parcels in the National Forest, and "National Forest" as the Arapaho-Roosevelt National Forests in Colorado. The term "National Forest" refers to the Arapaho-Roosevelt National Forests in Colorado, while "non-Federal land" is a 5.17-acre parcel in Boulder County, Colorado. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Agriculture. SEC. 3. LAND EXCHANGE. Land exchange authorized under the Act allows the District to convey non-Federal land to the Secretary in exchange for Federal land. The Secretary must accept the offer, and upon receiving acceptable title, convey Federal land to the District. The exchange is subject to applicable laws, with the Secretary able to accept cash payments exceeding 25% of the Federal land value. The land exchange authorized under the Act allows the District to convey non-Federal land to the Secretary in exchange for Federal land. The District must pay for land surveys and appraisals, and allocate administrative costs with the Secretary. The exchange is subject to valid existing rights, any terms the Secretary may require, and must be completed within 1 year of the Act's enactment. The Secretary may offer to sell Federal land to the District at fair market value if the land exchange is not completed within 1 year. Proceeds from the sale will be deposited into the fund established under the Sisk Act. The Secretary may deposit proceeds from cash equalization payments and sales under the Sisk Act for land acquisition in the National Forest. Acquired non-Federal land will be added to the National Forest and managed according to the Weeks Law. The Secretary can deposit proceeds from cash equalization payments and sales under the Sisk Act for land acquisition in the National Forest, managed according to the Weeks Law. Any public order withdrawing Federal land is revoked to allow conveyance to the District, and the Federal land is withdrawn if not already segregated under public land laws. The Federal land is withdrawn until the date of conveyance to the District under the Geothermal Steam Act of 1970. The Federal land was withdrawn until the date of conveyance to the District under the Geothermal Steam Act of 1970. Passed the House of Representatives on July 13, 2010.
